title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Chanchalapathi Dasa | SB 3.15.38 | 26-02-2016
speaker: HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

segments.key_quote: The Supreme Lord cannot be seen by ordinary eyes But he now became visible to the eyesight of the Kumaras
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Supreme Lord is not visible to ordinary eyes but became visible to the Kumaras due to their devotion and meditation.

segments.key_quote: That devotees being elevated in love of God Always see Shama Sundara, the Supreme Personality of Godhead Within their hearts But when they are mature The same God is visible before them face to face
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how devotees, through love of God and devotional service, can see the Lord within their hearts and eventually face to face.

segments.key_quote: So we are seeing in this part of the Srimad Bhagavatam The sages Were upset with the two doorkeepers and they cursed them Just then the Lord appeared Along with his consort Lakshmi Devi
segments.summary: The speaker describes the scene in the Srimad Bhagavatam where the Lord appears with his consort and associates, carrying various paraphernalia.

segments.key_quote: The sages now saw Vishnu The sages now saw Vishnu Now he had become An object of their sight
segments.summary: The speaker describes the sages seeing Vishnu and the pleasant atmosphere created by the chamara fan, comparing the carriers to white swans.

segments.key_quote: They were also carrying a Shubhra Atapatra. They were carrying an umbrella and it was a white umbrella.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the white umbrella adorned with pearls, using poetic language to compare it to the moon and nectar.

segments.key_quote: This is a description of the grand appearance of the Lord. This should give us a sense about the Lord's majestic opulence, the regality, that surrounds Him, and the opulences, and how He appears.
segments.summary: The speaker summarizes the description of the Lord's grand appearance, emphasizing his majestic opulence and regality.

segments.key_quote: When the Lord appears, He appears with His consort most of the time, and with His associates, all of them carrying different paraphernalia, and in that way, the Lord appears.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Lord typically appears with his consort and associates, and this helps us understand the Lord's position in Vaikuntha.

segments.key_quote: Some years ago, we had a president of India, visiting our temple here, and we had gone and invited him, in Delhi, and then he agreed to come, and when he came, there were a lot of preparations made
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of the President of India visiting their temple, highlighting the extensive preparations and the large entourage that accompanied him.

segments.key_quote: When the Lord is appearing, naturally, and he also has his associates and entourage, all of them appear, and it's a grand appearance.
segments.summary: The speaker draws a parallel between the President's entourage and the Lord's associates, then introduces the concept of anthropomorphism.

segments.key_quote: Some people think and say, that our human ideas, we are imposing on, God. So this is called, anthropomorphic concepts.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the idea that some people believe religious concepts are human ideas imposed on God, dismissing them as mythology.

segments.key_quote: If you study, none of the Acharyas, including Mayavadi Acharyas, will say like this. Especially the Vaishnava Acharyas. They never, derided, these as mythological, stories.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the anthropomorphic view with the traditional understanding of Acharyas, who do not dismiss these concepts as mere mythology.

segments.key_quote: Srila Prabhupada, like here it is explained in this verse. He is, Achakshata, Akshavishayam. Vishnu, is not Akshavishayam. He is not a Indriyavishaya.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's perspective that Krishna is not accessible to the mundane senses and is transcendental.

segments.key_quote: Krishna's reality, the reality of Krishna or Vishnu, is inaccessible, to our mundane senses. Our mundane senses can only access, a certain amount of reality.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Krishna's reality is beyond the reach of our limited mundane senses, which can only perceive a fraction of reality.

segments.key_quote: Just because our phone, our instruments, cannot reach out, we cannot say such a reality does not exist.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a mobile phone unable to make international calls to illustrate that the limitations of our instruments do not negate the existence of a higher reality.

segments.key_quote: This is the principle that is used by the Acharyas, by Srila Prabhupada. Srila Prabhupada gave very contemporary articulation of this idea, that this reality, this spiritual reality is beyond the access, beyond the powers of our senses.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the spiritual reality is beyond the reach of our senses, but there is a process to perceive the Lord, such as through samadhi.

segments.key_quote: yadangri abhidhyana samadhi dhautaya dhiyanupasyanti hi tatvam atmanah
segments.summary: The speaker quotes verses from the Bhagavatam, particularly Shukadeva Goswami's prayers, explaining how one can perceive the transcendental reality by meditating on the lotus feet of the Lord and purifying their intelligence.

segments.key_quote: Most people don't take the trouble of actually following the process, purifying the senses, purifying their consciousness by intense meditation, absorption on the lotus feet of the Lord. And hence they don't have a perception of the truth.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that most people don't achieve true realization due to a lack of dedication and instead rely on mental speculation, contrasting this with the Hamsa Guhyas prayers.

segments.key_quote: Only ones whose heart has become completely pure, such people, can be experienced, that Lord, when one is in a state of complete purity, one will be able to experience the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the Hamsa Guhyas prayers and emphasizes that only those with pure hearts, in a state of complete absorption, can experience the Lord.

segments.key_quote: When our consciousness is saturated, spiritually saturated, in that state, one can perceive. This is the message in the Vedic literatures consistently.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights the consistent message in Vedic literature that spiritual perception requires a consciousness saturated with transcendental service.

segments.key_quote: If we want to have a perception, a spiritual perception, a transcendental experience, we have to have, these words indicate, there is a certain amount of intensity, there is a certain amount of dedication, and absorption, that is essential.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the need for intensity, dedication, and absorption in spiritual practice, acknowledging the difficulties that may arise in service.

segments.key_quote: We should remember, what is the purpose of our existence? What is the purpose of our, what we are doing? Isn't it for that single purpose, of that spiritual experience, that we have come to Krishna Consciousness?
segments.summary: The speaker reminds the audience that the purpose of their existence in Krishna Consciousness is to achieve spiritual experience, which requires dedication and intensity.

segments.key_quote: Bhagavatam is gradually, training us, about the transcendental reality. Gradually understanding. Because the highest conception of the absolute truth, is not even Vishnu. It is Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Bhagavatam gradually trains us about transcendental reality, leading to the understanding that Krishna is the highest conception of the absolute truth, even beyond Vishnu.

segments.key_quote: So, we can see here how, the Bhagavatam is gradually, training us, about the transcendental reality. Gradually understanding.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing how the Bhagavatam gradually prepares us to understand the transcendental realm, including the interactions and pastimes in Vaikuntha, to better understand Krishna's reality.
